    publications

    The promise and limitations of synthetic data as a strategy to expand access to state-level multi-agency longitudinal data Permalink

    Published in Journal of Research on Educational Effectiveness, 2019

    Bonnéry, D., Feng, Y., Henneberger, A. K., Johnson, T. L., Lachowicz, M., Rose, B. A., Shaw, T., Stapleton, L. M., Woolley, M. E., & Zheng, Y. (2019). The promise and limitations of synthetic data as a strategy to expand access to state-level multi-agency longitudinal data. Journal of Research on Educational Effectiveness, 12(4), 616-647.

    Latent growth models with floors, ceilings, and random knots Permalink

    Published in Multivariate Behavioral Research, 2019

    Feng, Y., Hancock, G. R., & Harring, J. R. (2019). Latent growth models with floors, ceilings, and random knots. Multivariate Behavioral Research, 54(5), 751-770. doi: 10.1080/00273171.2019.1580556.

    Book review for Structural equation modeling: Applications using Mplus Permalink

    Published in Psychometrika, 2020

    Feng, Y., & Harring, J. R. (2020). Book review for Structural equation modeling: Applications using Mplus. Psychometrika, 85(2), 526-530.

    Abstract: An analytical framework for research questions with variability as the outcome or predictor Permalink

    Published in Multivariate Behavioral Research, 2020

    Feng, Y., & Hancock, G. R. (2020). Abstract: An analytical framework for research questions with variability as the outcome or predictor. Multivariate Behavioral Research, 55(1), 144-145.

    Oh no! They cut my funding! Using “post hoc” planned missing data designs to salvage longitudinal research Permalink

    Published in Child Development, 2021

    Feng, Y., & Hancock, G. R. (2021). Oh no! They cut my funding! Using “post hoc” planned missing data designs to salvage longitudinal research. Child Development, 92(3), 1199-1216.

    Model-based incremental validity Permalink

    Published in Psychological Methods, 2022

    Feng, Y., & Hancock, G. R. (2022). Model-based incremental validity. Psychological Methods, 27(6), 1039–1060. https://doi.org/10.1037/met0000342
